==== Rumours of Mubarak's family's departure ====
  â
[[Gamal Mubarak]], President Hosni Mubarak's sonâwho has been widely tipped as his successorâwas reported by the US-based Arabic website Akhbar al-Arab to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January 2011.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the end' for Egypt's Mubarak as son and wife flee|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Al Jazeera's reporter in Cairo said that Gamal remained in Cairo and was attending a meeting of the ruling National Democratic Party.<ref name="aljazeera-448"/>
 
==== Stock market ====
==== Stock market ====
Line 190: Line 187:
On 28 January, [[Fitch Ratings]] changed Egypt's rating outlook to negative from stable, saying the upsurge in protests adds uncertainty to the political and economic outlook.<ref name="Bloomberg-Muslim-Brotherhood">{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-s-muslim-botherhood-says-police-detain-senior-leaders-after-protests.html|title=Mubarak Faces His Biggest Challenge Amid Nationwide Protests|date=2011-01-28|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Vivian Salama, Ola Galal and Caroline Alexander}}</ref> Egyptian dollar-denominated bond yields also rose to a record high as oil prices rose and global stock market indices sank.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/asian-stocks-fall-for-first-time-in-five-days-on-japan-outlook-oil-slides.html|title=Oil Jumps, Stocks Retreat Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Stephen Kirkland|date=2011-01-28}}</ref> International [[gold]] prices jumped the most in 12 weeks by over US$20 to US$1341.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/gold-rises-from-lowest-since-october-on-outlook-for-u-s-interest-rates.html</ref> The international price of oil rose US$3.70 (4.3%) to US$89.34 on concern the instability would spread, the highest price since September 2009.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html</ref>
On 28 January, [[Fitch Ratings]] changed Egypt's rating outlook to negative from stable, saying the upsurge in protests adds uncertainty to the political and economic outlook.<ref name="Bloomberg-Muslim-Brotherhood">{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-s-muslim-botherhood-says-police-detain-senior-leaders-after-protests.html|title=Mubarak Faces His Biggest Challenge Amid Nationwide Protests|date=2011-01-28|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Vivian Salama, Ola Galal and Caroline Alexander}}</ref> Egyptian dollar-denominated bond yields also rose to a record high as oil prices rose and global stock market indices sank.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/asian-stocks-fall-for-first-time-in-five-days-on-japan-outlook-oil-slides.html|title=Oil Jumps, Stocks Retreat Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Stephen Kirkland|date=2011-01-28}}</ref> International [[gold]] prices jumped the most in 12 weeks by over US$20 to US$1341.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/gold-rises-from-lowest-since-october-on-outlook-for-u-s-interest-rates.html</ref> The international price of oil rose US$3.70 (4.3%) to US$89.34 on concern the instability would spread, the highest price since September 2009.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html</ref>
  +   +
==== Rumours of Mubarak's family's departure ====
  +
[[Gamal Mubarak]], President Hosni Mubarak's sonâwho has been widely tipped as his successorâwas reported by the US-based Arabic website Akhbar al-Arab to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January 2011.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the end' for Egypt's Mubarak as son and wife flee|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Al Jazeera's reporter in Cairo said that Gamal remained in Cairo and was attending a meeting of the ruling National Democratic Party.<ref name="aljazeera-448"/>
